Dear Amy Harding:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
February 12, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (d) Three references obtained from persons
who are unrelated to the staff person.
One of eight new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that three
references were obtained prior to hire as required.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (e) A record of any convictions other than
minor traffic violations from either of the
following:
• (i) The Michigan state police, tribal
police, or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law
2

enforcement agency where the
person usually resides.
One of eight new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that
ICHAT clearances were obtained prior to hire as required.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (h) Documentation from the department
that the person has not been named in a
central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any
state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
Two of eight new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that
Central Registry (CR) clearances were obtained prior to hire as required.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
• (a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or
not later than 6 months after the staff
member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation,
a written evaluation must be conducted
every 12 months.
Eight of eleven employee files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
3

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the licensing
recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (4) Before completion of the written report
required by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency
shall provide the foster parent with a verbal
summary of the preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not have documentation the foster
parent was provided a verbal summary of preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the investigation as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
• (b) Child’s date of birth.
• (c) Available known information about the
child’s health.
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
• (e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement
or replacement of the child.
4

• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster child
and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the
foster home as provided in federal law.
• (i) Name of the assigned social service
worker.
• (j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal

• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP)-within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP)-within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP)-within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, stepdown
from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
Three of six foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS 1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
6

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Six of six foster care files reviewed, and two of two independent living files reviewed
(17 of 34 service plans) did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent
agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
2/1/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/10/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
7

• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is temporary
court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
schedule appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Update HR new hire checklist to ensure all required clearances are
obtained prior to hire. Consultant to provide list of state contacts for central
registry requests.
• Regularly review youth’s physical information so that is it up to date on
service plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. A special evaluation was initiated on 11/27/2023 regarding allegations a
licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline. The licensed
foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A
CAP was approved on 12/27/2023 and continues to be implemented.
A special evaluation was initiated on 5/31/2023 regarding allegations a licensed
foster parent was using inappropriate physical punishment as discipline. The
licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A CAP was approved on 6/23/2023 and was successfully completed on
8/25/2023.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: SIR
2023C0000350 was initiated on 3/30/2023 regarding allegations the agency did
not provide adequate services to a foster child and biological mother and the
agency did not adequately document home visits and quality visits. The
investigation determined violation of rule 400.12207 (3) (a) staff responsibilities. A
CAP was approved on 9/6/2023 and continues to be implemented.
SIR 2023C0000635 was initiated on 7/20/2023 regarding allegations the agency
refused to give a foster child's personal belongings when moving from one
placement to another, the agency prevented a child from returning to school for
over a month and the agency risked child safety by ignoring a child's request to be
9

moved to another placement and threats of cutting and running away. The
investigation determined a violation of rule 400.12316 (1) (a) personal
possessions, rule 400.12409 education policy and rule 400.12404 placement. A
CAP was approved on 9/1/2023 and continues to be implemented.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 1/26/2023 with a corrective action plan approved
on 2/15/2023. During the review the agency had sixteen violations. Nine violations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. Four of the citations
found during this year’s inspection were repeats from the 2023 renewal. Five of
the citations found during this year’s inspection were repeats from the past two
inspections. During this period under review the agency noted that overall
compliance was impacted, by staffing and performance issues.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency's difficulty in meeting requirements during
this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the agency has had
consistent issues with staffing and performance regarding following through with
policies and processes. In addition, the agency experienced difficulty in
maintaining appropriate staffing levels. There were several occasions throughout
the year where the supervisor and Associate Director were expected to carry
caseloads. Because of this, it was challenging to monitor and provide the
appropriate supervision and support to staff.
The CA indicated the agency HR department is in the process of developing a
more effective performance evaluation and does not anticipate this being a citation
in the future. In addition, there was a staffing change made at the supervision level
and the Chief Administrator expressed confidence that several areas will improve
over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported supervisors
meet with them regularly and coworkers are available as needed if issues arise.
Staff reported feeling supported by the agency and had no concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. Records are stored securely.
10

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified the following safety concerns:
Safety Alert #1: Licensed foster home did not comply with Agency Analyst's multiple
requests to conduct a home visit.
Resolution: Agency completed a special investigation based on rule 400.9206 Foster
home evaluation. Revocation of the foster home license is currently being pursued.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
